title: Two Jews, Three Opinions and the Shroud of Turin
post:
Dan, PLEASE, FOR THE SAKE OF INTELLECTUAL HONESTY, don’t you misinterpret my words  nor misquote me.
 I had written: “. . . Barrie’s argument is very weak and his opinion not qualified.” (October 24, 2011 at 11:21 am | #16) ONLY IN REFERENCE TO Barrie Schwortz writing Yannick Clément: 
“if they did use coins, they certainly would not have put a pagan Caesar coin on the face of the prophesized Messiah!”. 
AllI wanted to say is How can Barrie be so sure? As a technical photographer and no matter how Jewish he is, Barrie is definitedly just not qualified to judge in archaeological and numismatics matter. He is neither a numismatic scholar nor a profesional numismatist that I know of. Are your criticisms only one way?
author: Max Patrick Hamon

title: Two Jews, Three Opinions and the Shroud of Turin
post:
“These are strong opinions from Hamon – ad hominem charges. They are not qualified that I can see.” (Dan’s quote)
Barrie is a  very exquite man, a great technical photographer and have created a wonderful website, no question. 
STILL 
NOT ONLY Barrie MAY WELL BE WRONG IN HIS OPINION (and I do think he is)
(Pilate coin symbols were not just pagan coins as he claims for sure. Through 2nd Temple  Judeans, they may were indeed  look ambivalent  as they were specifically designed not only to abide by the 2nd commandment but to be used by Judeans on a daily basis)
BUT HE IS ALSO WRONG IN HIS FACTS
(He did mistake Body image and Blood Visual Resolution Limits when it comes to the coin-on-eye issue AND his final assertion that Frei did not lifted up any sticky tape sample on the Shroud face is in rather sharp contrast with the very FACT Frei DID LIFT UP at least one sticky tape sample from the right cheek of the Man of the Shroud) 
Are my opinions not qualified and Barrie’s qualified. If  thisso, in your eyes,would mean the Shroud Science World has gone totally crazy!
